column2: Oh, John, how late you are! said Amelia, slipping out from the back parlour as he let himself in with his latch-key.

column2: Yes, I am;--very late, said John, taking his candle, and passing her by on the stairs without another word.

column3: But be it always remembered that there are two modes in which a young man may be free and easy with his elder and superior,--the mode pleasant and the mode offensive.

column2: Had it been in Johnny's nature to try the latter, the earl's back would soon have been up at once, and the play would have been over.
column3: Had it been in Johnny's nature to try the latter, the earl's back would soon have been up at once, and the play would have been over.

column2: But it was not in Johnny's nature to do so, and therefore it was that the earl liked him.
column3: But it was not in Johnny's nature to do so, and therefore it was that the earl liked him.

column2: At last came the hour of dinner on Tuesday, or at least the hour at which the squire had been asked to show himself at the Manor House. Eames, as by agreement with his patron, did not come down so as to show himself till after the interview.
column3: At last came the hour of dinner on Tuesday, or at least the hour at which the squire had been asked to show himself at the Manor House. Eames, as by agreement with his patron, did not come down so as to show himself till after the interview.

column2: Lady Julia, who had been present at their discussions, had agreed to receive the squire; and then a servant was to ask him to step into the earl's own room.
column3: Lady Julia, who had been present at their discussions, had agreed to receive the squire; and then a servant was to ask him to step into the earl's own room.

column2: It was pretty to see the way in which the three conspired together, planning and plotting with an eagerness that was beautifully green and fresh.
column3: It was pretty to see the way in which the three conspired together, planning and plotting with an eagerness that was beautifully green and fresh.

column2: He can be as cross as an old stick when he likes it, said the earl, speaking of the squire; "and we must take care not to rub him the wrong way."
column3: He can be as cross as an old stick when he likes it, said the earl, speaking of the squire; "and we must take care not to rub him the wrong way."

column3: I shan't know what to say to him when I come down, said Johnny.

column2: Just shake hands with him and don't say anything, said Lady Julia.
column3: Just shake hands with him and don't say anything, said Lady Julia.

column2: I'll give him some port wine that ought to soften his heart, said the earl, "and then we'll see how he is in the evening."
column3: I'll give him some port wine that ought to soften his heart, said the earl, "and then we'll see how he is in the evening."

column2: Eames heard the wheels of the squire's little open carriage and trembled.
column3: Eames heard the wheels of the squire's little open carriage and trembled.

column2: The squire, unconscious of all schemes, soon found himself with Lady Julia, and within two minutes of his entrance was walked off to the earl's private room.
column3: The squire, unconscious of all schemes, soon found himself with Lady Julia, and within two minutes of his entrance was walked off to the earl's private room.

column2: Certainly, he said, "certainly;" and followed the man-servant.
column3: Certainly, he said, "certainly;" and followed the man servant.

column2: The earl, as he entered, was standing in the middle of the room, and his round rosy face was a picture of good-humour.
column3: The earl, as he entered, was standing in the middle of the room, and his round rosy face was a picture of good humour.

column2: I'm very glad you've come, Dale, said he.
column3: I'm very glad you've come, Dale, said he.

column2: I've something I want to say to you.
column3: I've something I want to say to you.

column2: Mr. Dale, who neither in heart nor in manner was so light a man as the earl, took the proffered hand of his host, and bowed his head slightly, signifying that he was willing to listen to anything.
column3: mr Dale, who neither in heart nor in manner was so light a man as the earl, took the proffered hand of his host, and bowed his head slightly, signifying that he was willing to listen to anything.

column2: I think I told you, continued the earl, "that young John Eames is down here; but he goes back to-morrow, as they can't spare him at his office.
column3: I think I told you, continued the earl, "that young john Eames is down here; but he goes back to morrow, as they can't spare him at his office.

column2: He's a very good fellow,--as far as I am able to judge, an uncommonly good young man.
column3: He's a very good fellow,--as far as I am able to judge, an uncommonly good young man.

column2: I've taken a great fancy to him myself."
column3: I've taken a great fancy to him myself."

column2: In answer to this Mr. Dale did not say much.
column3: In answer to this mr Dale did not say much.

column2: He sat down, and in some general terms expressed his good-will towards all the Eames family.
column3: He sat down, and in some general terms expressed his good will towards all the Eames family.

column2: As you know, Dale, I'm a very bad hand at talking, and therefore I won't beat about the bush in what I've got to say at present.	As you know, Dale, I'm a very bad hand at talking, and therefore I won't beat about the bush in what I've got to say at present.

column2: Of course we've all heard of that scoundrel Crosbie, and the way he has treated your niece Lilian."

column2: But the less we say about that the better.
column3: But the less we say about that the better.

column2: It is ill mentioning a girl's name in such a matter as that."
column3: It is ill mentioning a girl's name in such a matter as that."

column2: Dear young child, I would do anything to comfort her!
column3: Dear young child, I would do anything to comfort her!

column2: And I hope that something may be done to comfort her.
column3: And I hope that something may be done to comfort her.

column2: Do you know that that young man was in love with her long before Crosbie ever saw her?"
column3: Do you know that that young man was in love with her long before Crosbie ever saw her?"

column2: What;--John Eames!
column3: What;--john Eames!

column2: Yes, John Eames.	Yes, john Eames.

column2: A man cannot help these things, De Guest, said the squire.

column2: Just at present it wouldn't do, I suppose, to talk to her about a new sweetheart.
column3: Just at present it wouldn't do, I suppose, to talk to her about a new sweetheart.

column2: But, Dale, the time will come; the time will come;--the time always does come."
column3: But, Dale, the time will come; the time will come;--the time always does come."

column2: It has never come to you and me, said the squire, with the slightest possible smile on his dry cheeks.
column3: It has never come to you and me, said the squire, with the slightest possible smile on his dry cheeks.

column2: The story of their lives had been so far the same; each had loved, and each had been disappointed, and then each had remained single through life.
column3: The story of their lives had been so far the same; each had loved, and each had been disappointed, and then each had remained single through life.

column2: Yes, it has, said the earl, with no slight touch of feeling and even of romance in what he said.
column3: Yes, it has, said the earl, with no slight touch of feeling and even of romance in what he said.

column3: But for her,--you and her mother will look forward to see her married some day."

column2: Well, then, whether you do or not, I'll give him something, said the earl.

column2: Shall we go in to Lady Julia now?"

column3: If you will allow me I will think over what you have said, and then see you again."

column2: Certainly, certainly.

column2: But for your own part in the matter, for your great generosity and kind heart, I beg to offer you my warmest thanks. Then the squire bowed low, and preceded the earl out of the room.
column3: But for your own part in the matter, for your great generosity and kind heart, I beg to offer you my warmest thanks. Then the squire bowed low, and preceded the earl out of the room.

column2: Lord De Guest still felt that he had not succeeded.

column2: The good wine did in some sort soften the squire; but, as a matter of course, nothing further was said as to the new matrimonial scheme. The earl did observe, however, that Mr. Dale was civil, and even kind, to his own young friend, asking a question here and there as to his life in London, and saying something about the work at the Income-tax Office.
